Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2011 04:24PM Amykd wrote: Hi Jane207, For piece of mind you could take you images to another breast center for a second read to confirm the recomendation from the 1st center.  I did that because I wanted to make sure nothing was missed in the 1st read of my images. Amy
Posts.Title: What does this mean? Jane207 Amykd

Posts.Content: Apr 12, 2011 06:22PM Amykd wrote: So....I just wanted to post an update to my saga.  What I have learned is that waiting for tests sucks!! Waiting for 6 weeks for test after test sucks too but...there is a silver lining.  After mammo, diagostic mamo, ultrasound, sonocine, breast MRI, 5 mammotome biosies and a wire guided open biopsy....the final result is BENIGN!  Radial scar, mild hyperplasia, sclerosing adenosis...very busy breasts but benign all the same.  My BS said I will require continued follow up for a long time because of slight family history, dense  & busy breasts and premenopausal and such.  That is okay. For now I can exhale.  Here's hoping those of you waiting for results (mine was Birads 4) will also get to hear BENIGN.  It does happen!  Thanks for reading and supporting me Amy
Posts.Title: Radial Scar-Scared AGAIN Amykd Amykd

Posts.Content: Amykd wrote: Hi Everyone, Okay...so updated information!  I finally spoke to the breast surgeon and while everything is benign, I have an area that is sclerosing adenosis, hyperplasia (without atypia) and a small radial scar.  I am now scheduled for a wire loc. removal of that radial scar due to the fact that this might be hiding a low grade cancer (what my BS said). Does anyone have further information about radial scars, experience with them and possibly hiding cancer cells?  Also, what is a wire loc removal like?  I am so, so grateful for my benign results but I am now scared that they missed something in the ultrasound core biopsy.  Any information would be helpful...it is a rollercoaster ride and I would like to get off now (sigh). Amy  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Radial Scar-Scared AGAIN Amykd Amykd

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2011 09:51PM Amykd wrote: I agree with jo1955.  A biopsy would be the 1st way to address the lump especially if you can feel it.  A mammotome biopsy (vacuum) is very accurate and much less invasive then open surgical removal.  I have now had both a mammotome and surgical removal.   The mammotome was not too bad-the worst part is the numbing medicine.  While I was scared of the anesthesia for the surgical removal, it worked out well with no problems. It was not full general more like a twilight sleep (like when I had my wisdom teeth out).   I certainly can understand your concern about feeling a lump.  I recently had a Sonocine ultrasound (3D ultrasound).  It is very accurate and highly sensitive. That is a test you could request-currently it is a self pay test ($300) because it is new.  It found 5 areas in both my breasts that did not show up on a regular ultrasound or Mammo due to breat density(waiting on surgical results for 1 area-radial scar).  Amy
